utterances: What was the situation like in terms of services, water, electricity, that sort of thing?
Water was present, but it was fairly dirty, actually.
Like, you know, you turn on the faucet and you'd see, you know, it wasn't the cleanest water in the world.
And the electricity, you'd have it on and off.

But at nighttime, since I went in the winter, we had a fairly, like, steady supply at night, which was, you know, when it mattered, because during the day it would be warm, but at night it would be fairly cold.
And in general, are you encouraged or are you optimistic?
I'm very much optimistic about the future.
I mean, it just seems like it's getting better by the, maybe, month or something.
Although there was a bombing today, but I don't think it will affect it that much.
OK.
Thanks very much for the call.
Appreciate it.
Thank you very much.
So long.
And I guess a measure in terms of how people feel about their lives.
Markets seem to be open again.
People seem to be willing to go out onto the streets in some places where before they didn't.
Michael, did you get that impression in Baghdad?
Yeah, you know, in Baghdad proper.

You know, the New York Times bureau is not in the Green Zone, it's outside the Green Zone, and so we just - in the area nearby and just driving around in the streets, you do see more people on the streets, more activity on the streets.
I think there's a definite change.
And outside of Baghdad, I was in Diwaniya, Kut, Najaf, Karbala, and I also sensed an improvement.
I know, and I think...
...For the last eight months.
And as correspondents, we sense it, because we either have to either go embedded or unembedded.

And a number of members of our bureau, like Alissa Rubin and others, have gone to places like Najaf unembedded, just in a car driving down there, and yes, we have to take precautions, but also the security is sufficiently improved that we feel comfortable taking those risks.
And do those things come across in your measurements?
Oh, absolutely, and I think some of the key statistics bear it out.
You know, at some of the heights of the violence, they were experiencing 150 attacks a day.
The May data shows 45.
I mean, that's an 80-percent drop in violence within Iraq.
And that's obviously significant.

So, obviously, keep an eye on it, and the Status of Forces Agreement, as that's negotiated, that's going to be of great interest because it will define the future relationship between the American forces in Iraq, what they are obligated to do for the Iraqis and what the Iraqis are obligated to do for the American forces, and the legality of groups like Blackwater, who prosecutes them and what law they're treated under.
That's going to be a very important thing.
Progress on the oil law, and as a Michael Gordon said earlier, these elections that are coming up in the fall, October, November, probably December.
The timing is not exactly right.
We'll keep an eye on it.
Michael Gordon, thanks very much for your time.
Thank you.
Michael Gordon, chief military correspondent for the New York Times, and Joseph Christoff, very good to have you on the program today.
Thank you.
Joseph Christoff, the director of international affairs and trade at the Government Accountability Office.
They were both with us here in Studio 3A.
Coming up, does this sound familiar?
No gifts, please.
Just send money.
Ask Amy's"" Amy Dickenson weighs in on potluck weddings.
Should guests be asked to help pay for the parson?
Email us, talk@npr.org.
Stay with us.
I'm Neal Conan.
It's the Talk of the Nation from NPR News.

This is Don Gonyea traveling with the Obama campaign, which got on the road early yesterday morning after the debate, traveling to a pair of rallies south of the Mason Dixon line, states that have long been reliably Republican.
Here's the candidate just past noon.
Thank you, North Carolina!
It's good to be back.
I love North Carolina.
(Soundbite of crowd cheering and chanting ""Obama"")
And then early in the evening he was in the town of Fredericksburg.
It is a thrill to be here, back in Virginia, because I think we may just turn Virginia blue this time.
(Soundbite of crowd cheering)
Obama's theme all day Saturday was Friday night's debate with John McCain, and he went straight to McCain's handling of the crisis facing the U.S.
financial system.
He talked about the economy for 40 minutes, and not once did Senator McCain talk about the struggles of middle-class families.
Not once did he talk about what they're facing every day right here in North Carolina and around the country.

He defended the plan to give $300 billion in tax cuts to corporations and the wealthiest Americans, but he had nothing to say about the fact that wages have flat lined and jobs are being shipped overseas.
He didn't have anything to say about that.
In both Greensborough and in Fredericksburg, Obama followed with this new punch line.
The truth is through 90 minutes of debate, John McCain had a lot to say about me, but he had nothing to say about you.
He didn't even say the word middle class.
Didn't say the word working people.
See, I think Senator McCain just doesn't get it.
The Obama campaign's clear goal is to put Senator McCain permanently on the defensive about the economy.
Polls show the public has more confidence in Obama than McCain on what has become the number one issue this year, and the Democratic nominee is trying to exploit that.
Later on Saturday giving his one speech of the day via satellite to the U.S.
Sportsmen's Alliance, McCain did add a reference to the middle class when talking about the need to reach a deal to rescue financial institutions.
Meanwhile, yesterday Obama was joined on the trail by his running mate, Joe Biden.
Biden made no mention of his own upcoming debate four days from now with Republican vice presidential nominee Sarah Palin.
Today, Obama and Biden will campaign together again in Detroit.
Don Gonyea, NPR News, Fredericksburg, Virginia.
Next, we have a mystery.
It's what keeps some people from turning a small business success into a big one.
If a business does well, after all, a natural next step is to expand.
Around the world, many farmers, who are, after all, business people, do not expand.
If their farms are part of a developing country, that matters.
So Robert Smith of NPR's Planet Money podcast asked what holds them back.
The first step in solving the mystery is to find an amazing farmer.
My name is Blessing Nkhase.
Blessing is definitely the best apple grower in the tiny African country of Lesotho.
We do have Golden Delicious, Fuji.
Fuji?
Yes.
Yes.
We do have a Granny Smith.
Granny Smith?
Yes.
These are the same we have in the United States.
Yeah, yeah, yeah.
Now, Blessing has empty fields.
And the economically rational thing to do would be to grow more apples.
He really is the best at it.
And Blessing explains that if he had the money, he would.
I thought it was surprising that Kyle Sampson would start out saying that's a largely artificial distinction.
I think he means, yes, we wanted prosecutors to follow the president's priorities; for example, bring immigration cases.
But he didn't really put to rest the concern that it could have been political in the big P sense of that term, partisan.
Yeah.

That the, for example, the federal prosecutor in San Diego who was apparently following up on the Duke Cunningham investigation - he is now in prison, of course - that she may have been prosecuted for - or she may have been dismissed for basically pursuing Republicans.
Yes.
Absolutely.

And you know, the prosecutor from New Mexico, David Iglesias, says that Pete Domenici, the Republican senator, and Heather Wilson called him on the phone and said in effect why aren't you moving on bringing charges against Democrats right before the election?
That sure sounds political.
Heather Wilson, of course, the congresswoman from New Mexico who may hope to succeed Mr. Domenici to the United States Senate.
Anyway, later in his statement, the attorney general's former chief of staff seemed to be falling on his sword.
Mr. Gonzales said mistakes were made and he told the committee I made them.
This was in terms of his - he is admitting to the mishandling of how the dismissals were announced and what people were told and then misinformation that may have been told to Congress.
Yes.
I thought you're going to run a tape of him, a clip of that.
But yes, his point was that we did a poor job of communicating it.
Yes, it wasn't that we made a poor decision; we - he didn't exactly explain, in the end, how they picked the attorneys to be - the prosecutors to be fired.
He said I had sort of a list, and some senators said, well, can we see the list?
And he said it wasn't really a list, I had some notes.
